abbreviations.ESDIS: Earth Science Data and Information System

children.value: There are a range of data products generated by the
mission team that are archived and available for immediate use, from raw data to analysis-ready products.
One of the most exciting aspects of the
mission is that it generates a number of analysis-ready
products are archived and freely available to the public. This allows users without the software or expertise necessary to process
data easy access to products that can be used in analysis workflows.
scientists and those who want to generate products to their own specifications, the
The NASA processing levels used for

have somewhat different meanings than those used for multi-spectral (optical) imagery. We will summarize these processing levels and the specific products generated by the mission at each level and provide links to additional information about each product type.
illustrates the products that will be generated in association with the
mission, indicating the products used as input. Level 0 through Level 2 products will be produced directly by the mission and archived at ASF, as will the Level 3 Soil Moisture products.
The remaining Level 3-4 products in the figure will be produced by the

science team, but only for specific areas used for calibration and validation activities. Some of these cal/val products may be archived and available to the public. The processing workflows for these higher-level products will be made available as Python notebooks as they are validated, allowing users to generate these scientific products themselves for other locations.

children.alt: Figure of NISAR products indicating input data types and processing roles

children.value: TODO: update links to go to the product overview headings rather than the .md

Level 0 products are unprocessed instrument data. L0A products are the received raw data, which are archived for reference but are not of use to the scientific community. L0B products have been processed to remove transmission artifacts, and are the starting point for processing all additional mission products. They are generally only of interest to
L0B product contains corrected, aligned radar pulse data.

Level 1 products are processed instrument data, focused to full resolution complex images. They are time referenced and annotated with ancillary information, including radiometric and relevant geometric calibration coefficients and georeferencing parameters (i.e. platform ephemeris). Level 1 products are in natural radar coordinates, and cannot be directly overlaid on a map.
images in range-Doppler coordinates. Other pair-based Level 1 products are derived from this product.
product represents the ellipsoid height-corrected, wrapped interferogram generated from two
product is primarily meant for detecting grounding lines.
product represents a collection of dense pixel offsets layers obtained from applying speckle tracking to a pair of coarsely coregistered
product is primarily meant for cryosphere applications.
product represents the unwrapped, multi-looked differential interferogram generated from two
product primarily supports the solid earth requirement of ground surface displacement measurements.
Level 2 products are derived from Level 1 products, resampled and geocoded to a geographic grid. They can be directly overlaid on a map and combined with other data in geographic coordinates.
product represents the single look complex signal return for each polarization in geographic coordinates. The
product enables users to perform backscatter amplitude analysis, and can be combined with other similar
products to derive interferograms and change maps.

ecosystem requirements of biomass estimation, soil moisture estimation, disturbance detection, inundation mapping, and crop area delineation.

product primarily supports the solid earth requirement of ground surface displacement measurements.
Level 3 products represent geophysical parameters derived from radar-specific parameters and geocoded to a geographic grid.
product contains soil moisture estimates derived from

data using three different algorithms at agricultural field-scale (200m) posting for most regions (the Sahara Desert will be at 500m).  Soil moisture information can be used for reservoir management, early warning of droughts, irrigation scheduling, and crop yield forecasting.
